displayed_text: Patient: Nooo, I don’t think so. I think, I’m just wound up. Doctor: Oh well, again, I’ll ask the other time, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know, is there anything bringing you joy, anything like that. You know, but you’re going through a lot, and it certainly, uh, can weigh heavily, and that’s normal. Patient: Yeah. Yeah, and Doctor: And again, I worry about when you don’t wanna get out of bed, you don’t Patient: Mmm Doctor: wanna do anything, you don’t, you know if there’s anything that sort of Patient: No. And, and with the kind of work that I do, it’s not unusual to get in at two or three in the morning, have to get up at six in the morning, and you just, you have to drive on. You sleep for three hours in the afternoon, and then you go to work at six at night and work until eleven. And then, it, it just is part of what I do. Um, so. Doctor: Okay. And, uh, last time we talked - Family Member: So, as a, a young man he worked the night shifts- Patient: Oh, yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: We’re done. Doctor: Oh yes, I’m just checking. And how is it? Do you love it? Family Member: Yeah, it’s uh; we have to make some changes but yeah, it feels like home. Doctor: That’s awesome, no ladders for you, right? Family Member: I had to argue with him about it. Patient: Could I give away all my ladders? Doctor: Did you put it in the garage sale? I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder. Patient: So what makes you think I may have fallen again? Doctor: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did. Patient: Oh. Doctor: But it might have been last time. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Yep. For two weeks. Two weeks off, two weeks on. Doctor: You still on the Zoloda? Today? Patient: Yes. Doctor: per day any other medicine vitamins? Patient: Yes. Doctor: multivitamin steady today? Patient: two more pills; Optim- and two more pills Patient: real small pill Doctor: It’s a eye drop or a pill? Patient: It’s a pill. Oral. (pause) Doctor: The , how much do you take of that? Patient: I think it’s ten milligrams, small Doctor: One capsule a day?

Patient: Yeah, yeah, that’s - Doctor: Then you’re taking Vitamin D, a thousand units a day. Patient: Doing that. Doctor: And uh so (_-pine name of drug) Patient: Yes. Doctor: And it looks like it’s working and then Oxybutynin for bladder spasms. Patient: Okay, I had - I had some urinary infection, and they gave me seven days’ uh - Family Member: I think Patient: And I finished that last night. Doctor: And so did they give you something also for spasms? Patient: No. Doctor: So Oxybutynin. Family Member: Uh well yes, they did but he decided not to take that.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And there’s actually a group that would get you back to California. There’s a group at UCLA (laughs) Patient: And how does, what’s the effect of that when you get treated? I mean what is, what’s different about that? Would that, would that go after the growth in the lymph nodes? Doctor: Yes. So PSMA is a thing that’s on the surface of crossing cancer cells. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And it’s an enzyme, which means uh we’re not really sure what it does but we are, we’re able to block its function with a with a small drug. Uh and what people actually here when we started doing it, uh people thought well that would be cool to take an image of the cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which will see where it is. So we put a little radioactive tag- Patient: Okay. Doctor: and the only PSMA does is go from the surface inside the cancer cell, and it’s almost, it’s almost a way to build something up inside. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we can get a really nice picture. Well, the next easy lead from there is why not put something that’s a killer mode. Uh what they’ve seen, and what’s been published in the German, mostly Germany, it’s relatively nontoxic. Uh the big toxicity has been uh the salivary glands seem to make PSMA also. So some people end up with dry mouth uh as a side effect. Uh the kidney also makes P- PSMA. They haven’t really reported acute kidney damage, hasn’t really been a big issue, but they haven’t really followed the people long enough I think to know-

Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time. Doctor: Yeah and by then we’ll know what trial makes sense um to offer… Patient: You know I do see on the internet, I think it was a… Doctor: Yeah Patient: British article about immunotherapy with prostate cancer… Doctor: Mhmm, Yes. Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA?

Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know. Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes.

Patient: No. Doctor: What about bending it? No? Patient: Um no. Family Member: xxx].I’ll tell you what I did. I, I, still play paddleball which is like racquetball. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And occasionally I’ll swing I’ll get a zinger down here and that’s from back there you know. And the neurologist told me to quit playing. Doctor: Yeah I was gonna ask you did you check with the neurosurgeon if it’s safe to do it. Patient: Oh yeah. Nah, it’s not safe. Doctor: It doesn’t sound safe. Patient: No. Doctor: Oh you’re just preferring to not get … Patient: Well I got a…

Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so the thing that was the nuance when, uh, the nurse called you the other day? Patient: Uh huh? Doctor: Is what we have found is that people who are on the Xtandi or enzalutamide may have a better likelihood of responding to these medicines. Patient: Oh. I see. Doctor: So, where you don’t qualify for this study is you’re not on Xtandi now. Patient: Right.

Healthcare Professional: I’ve got to take his chart to the closet so I can get his drug going. Here is the dose of Taxol that you’re getting. This is just the side effects sheet that S___ will talk to you about. (papers shuffling) Doctor: Right just the name and – so the Prednisone, we will need to start along with the chemo. You know it helps the chemo work better. So that you’re going to go back on morning and evening, five milligrams. Family Member: Okay. HCP She can just leave it right there Doctor: So that is something I’ll need to send in. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then I’ll send in the Zofran or what do you want to do? Should I send it in to the same? You haven’t changed pharmacists? HCP She’s Family Member: Okay. Doctor: All right, have a good holiday. I guess I’ll see you after now. Family Member: Yes, you also. Don’t forget your candy. Doctor: Yes (Laughs) Patient: I actually brought it for knitting but. Doctor: But you decided to just, hey I work harder. (chuckles)

Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Family Member: I’m so sorry. Doctor: And if it does come back, we don’t know if will stay a little longer. Family Member: Right. Doctor: We just don’t know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s all, it’s sort of that kind of psychological. Patient: Yeah, okay. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: At some future date, you hope to have some answers to that? Doctor: Absolutely, but I won’t have them in the next five years.

Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I don’t get – there’s never a night that I get three or four hours uninterrupted sleep. Doctor: Cause you’re peeing? Patient: Um, yes. Doctor: Yeah. So what time do you stop drinking? Patient: Every time I get up, I drink some more water. (Laughter) Doctor: That’s why you keep peeing. Patient: But everybody told me to drink more water. Family Member: No. During the day. Doctor: During the day. You should shut your water drinking at seven o’clock. Doctor: Yes. And then you’ll stop peeing at night. And then you’ll wake up and drink all day until you stop at seven o’clock. Family Member: When they were doing the (Xofigo)

Patient: Yes.Yes Doctor: Have you, had you heard that before? Patient: Not really. No. Doctor: When you were, when you got treated with the radiation, did they present any other options for treatment at that point or was it just you have to have radiation. Patient: Just have to have radiation. Doctor: Alright. Patient: It wasn't really great in detail. Doctor: Okay, so this is the, this is the consent form for the MAP trial. So this is the MAP trial phase three, meaning that it's just more advanced and we're comparing it against placebo and it's a large trial. So I want you to take this home, I want you to read it, and I want you to think about it. I'll contact our research nurses too to see if you're eligible. And then we'll give you a call tomorrow and you can tell me. Yes, I think this is reasonable. Let's keep going. You can tell me- Patient: Trust me, I don’t have to wait until next week. Family Member: Trust me, he'll sign it right now. Patient: I’m serious. Family Member: I mean, he's ready to go. We kind of talked about it. Okay. Doctor: You know, so what were the discussion or what were you thinking or what were the discussions that you were having before?

Doctor: Thank goodness. Doctor: hhh Now, that is something. Even though, I yell at you sometimes. Patient: Right. Noooo, I’ve got, Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve got a lot of respect for you. Doctor: Thank you. Sit up for a minute. Let me, uh, put down. (Paper rattling) Patient: Mmm.hmmm. Doctor: Does that hurt? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay, how far can you bring it? (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: No? How about the other side? (Pause) Patient: That’s fine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. Especially, uh, you know we wouldn’t let you go if you weren’t feeling great. And I need to ask, the thing to ask M___, is you know if it gets too late, you know, could you stay a second night if you wanted to. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know? So if you’re pooped out, you just go home the next day. So we could ask her about that. Patient: I mean, I mean there are places I could go. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I got moved to the big house last week. Doctor: Oh. Patient: I don’t think I have the pictures any more. Doctor: And how do you feel about it? Patient: I was living like a king over there. You know? Patient: You go, you go in this room, and I would call that I mean if I was rich it would be a kids homework room It’s fourteen by maybe twenty.
